simulation.gui
Class SimulationMenu

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  simulation.gui.SimulationMenu
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class SimulationMenu
extends javax.swing.JPanel

This is the menu on the side of the simulation; it contains various options and buttons, particularly the play/step/pause commands.

Author:
Tikhon Jelvis
See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

SimulationMenu

public SimulationMenu(Simulation model,
                      MainWindow mainWindow)
Creates the menu. This constructor handles everything including all the buttons and options.

Method Detail

setSpeed

public void setSpeed(double speed)
Sets the speed of animation in frames per second. The speed has to be between 0 and 100; other values will lead to nothing happening. Calling this method while the animation is playing will cause the AnimationTask playing to be recreated and rescheduled with the new speed being used to determine the interval.

Parameters:
speed - - the new speed in frames per second. The speed can only be between 0 and 100; anything else will be ignored. A speed of 0 stops the animation.

getSpeed

public double getSpeed()
Returns the speed at which the simulation is or would be playing.

Returns:
speed - a value that represents the speed the simulation is or would be playing at.

setGoing

public void setGoing(boolean going)
Sets whether the animation is currently computing a step.

Parameters:
going - - whether the simulation is computing a step.

isGoing

public boolean isGoing()
Returns whether the simulation is currently computing a step. If it is, no action to it should be done for fear of ConcurrentModificationExceptions or undefined, unpredictable behavior.

Returns:
whether the simulation is currently computing a step.

setAccuracy

public void setAccuracy(int accuracy)
Sets the accuracy of the simulation. The bigger the number, the more accurate the simulation is. The numbers have no units; they are more-or- less arbitrary.

Parameters:
accuracy - - the accuracy of the simulation.

getAccuracy

public int getAccuracy()
Returns an int that corresponds to the accuracy of the simulation. The higher the int, the higher the accuracy.

Returns:
the accuracy of the simulation as an int.
